Story: Charlie's Big Day: A Glimpse into the Future
Excerpt:
Suddenly the DJ’s voice came through the speakers. “Ladies and gentlemen, we are clearing the floor for a very special couple.  Your hosts for the evening and the bride’s parents will now share a special dance celebrating twenty years of marriage.”  

Sophie looked at Ryan before she stood.  She straightened her jacket then held out a hand to Ryan.  “Dance with me, brat?”

“Always, Crowphie.”

Sophie led Ryan to the dance floor.  She smiled when she heard the song Charlie had chosen.  It was an old song called ‘Still’ by the artist Tamia.  Their daughter had chosen well.  The lyrics described them and their relationship perfectly.

Sophie swept Ryan into her arms and began to sing the lyrics. Very few people outside of their family knew Sophie had an amazing voice.  It had been honed by years of singing in her mother’s church choir.  She had once hated her ability because it brought so many bad memories with it.  Now, it was something she enjoyed, especially for Ryan because Ryan loved to hear her.

‘Usually when two people are together for a long time things seem to change.

It's been said that nothing good lasts forever, but this love gets better every day.

We get all excited inside every time that we get alone.

He still got love in his eyes, and I still got love in my soul

Still… feels like the first time we met

That I kissed and I told you I love you.

We still run around like teenagers even though we're grown and married with kids.

And we still talk on the phone for hours when I'm away.

And he still writes letters and sends me flowers every other day. 

The question everybody asks is how we make it last

I tell them I still. He still. We still’




Ryan stared into those familiar hazel eyes, the same eyes she’d fallen in love with so many years ago.  “I love you, Sophie Moore… still.”

“And I’m going to love you until the day I die, Ryan Wilder because I still.”  

With that, the world fell away, and it was just the two of them, soul mate to soul mate.  Sophie leaned down and brought their lips together in a loving kiss.  This wasn’t an ending. This was just a continuation of the greatest love story of all time.

Suddenly the DJ’s voice came through the speakers. “Ladies and gentlemen, we are clearing the floor for a very special couple.  Your hosts for the evening and the bride’s parents will now share a special dance celebrating twenty years of marriage.”  

Sophie looked at Ryan before she stood.  She straightened her jacket then held out a hand to Ryan.  “Dance with me, brat?”

“Always, Crowphie.”

Sophie led Ryan to the dance floor.  She smiled when she heard the song Charlie had chosen.  It was an old song called ‘Still’ by the artist Tamia.  Their daughter had chosen well.  The lyrics described them and their relationship perfectly.

Sophie swept Ryan into her arms and began to sing the lyrics. Very few people outside of their family knew Sophie had an amazing voice.  It had been honed by years of singing in her mother’s church choir.  She had once hated her ability because it brought so many bad memories with it.  Now, it was something she enjoyed, especially for Ryan because Ryan loved to hear her.

‘Usually when two people are together for a long time things seem to change.

It's been said that nothing good lasts forever, but this love gets better every day.

We get all excited inside every time that we get alone.

He still got love in his eyes, and I still got love in my soul

Still… feels like the first time we met

That I kissed and I told you I love you.

We still run around like teenagers even though we're grown and married with kids.

And we still talk on the phone for hours when I'm away.

And he still writes letters and sends me flowers every other day. 

The question everybody asks is how we make it last

I tell them I still. He still. We still’

 

Ryan stared into those familiar hazel eyes, the same eyes she’d fallen in love with so many years ago.  “I love you, Sophie Moore… still.”

“And I’m going to love you until the day I die, Ryan Wilder because I still.”  

With that, the world fell away, and it was just the two of them, soul mate to soul mate.  Sophie leaned down and brought their lips together in a loving kiss.  This wasn’t an ending. This was just a continuation of the greatest love story of all time.

Excerpt:
Planting a quick one on Ryan's lips, Sophie brought the box over to the kitchen island. After yanking off a blue ribbon, she lifted the lid and pulled back the tissue, her jaw dropping about the contents.




Inside the box were three vinyl records—not just any records, but her holy trinity of Jay-Z albums: Reasonable Doubt, Blueprint, and The Black Album. Each one was signed at the edge, in cursive script, "To my #1 fan, Sophie! Love, Hov."




"No way, no freaking way!" She held the autographed vinyls up like they were made of solid gold.




A big smile spread across Ryan's face, loving how her girl was tripping over the surprise. "I have my ways. Remember that Saturday about a month ago when I went out of town for the day? Well, I went to a Roc Nation dinner after putting myself—" Ryan coughed lightly, murmuring "hacking" under her breath, "—on the guest list. Had to do a little schmoozing to get him to sign, but how could he resist my charm? I told him we were the real Bonnie & Clyde, and he and Beyoncé ain't have nothing on us." She laughed, shaking her head. "Of course, I said that out of Queen Bey's earshot."

Planting a quick one on Ryan's lips, Sophie brought the box over to the kitchen island. After yanking off a blue ribbon, she lifted the lid and pulled back the tissue, her jaw dropping about the contents.

 

Inside the box were three vinyl records—not just any records, but her holy trinity of Jay-Z albums: Reasonable Doubt, Blueprint, and The Black Album. Each one was signed at the edge, in cursive script, "To my #1 fan, Sophie! Love, Hov."

 

"No way, no freaking way!" She held the autographed vinyls up like they were made of solid gold.

 

A big smile spread across Ryan's face, loving how her girl was tripping over the surprise. "I have my ways. Remember that Saturday about a month ago when I went out of town for the day? Well, I went to a Roc Nation dinner after putting myself—" Ryan coughed lightly, murmuring "hacking" under her breath, "—on the guest list. Had to do a little schmoozing to get him to sign, but how could he resist my charm? I told him we were the real Bonnie & Clyde, and he and Beyoncé ain't have nothing on us." She laughed, shaking her head. "Of course, I said that out of Queen Bey's earshot."

Story: Two Strippers Walk Into A Bar
Excerpt:
Ryan could see Sophie’s body relax and she smiled taking that as her answer.  The deep bass of Janet Jackson’s ‘Would You Mind’   floated through the speakers.  Sophie’s eyes were glued to Ryan’s as she began to move her body to the beat. 

Sophie was mesmerized.  She’d seen Ryan dance before; they’d gone dancing plenty of times together, but this was different.  This was sex in motion and it made Sophie squirm in her seat.

“Dang, I’m sorry Ry. How are you feeling?”

“Well let her know” Mary said

Excerpt:
Ryan was loving this domestic vibe. She was glad Sophie came through. She would never outwardly admit it but she was getting a lil scared that their relationship was becoming something on the back burner for Sophie. This moment solidified to her that she had nothing to worry about.




“Alright, dinner is served” 




Sophie plated their dinner and poured their wine. She sat at the island with Ryan. They ate their dinner as Floetry’s “Say Yes” played in the background. 




“Mmm, babe this is delicious” Ryan said, “I thought you said you couldn’t cook.”




“First off, thank you” Sophie continued, “but I never said I couldn’t cook, I said I wasn’t much of a cook.”
